Well it is,
but the thing about that number is it's
seemingly not interesting at all, okay? So
as of a a couple of days ago I've been
reliably informed that this is the

Integer Sequences. So this- this does
actually appear in a definition of a

first number not to appear at all is the
following number; so this is seemingly
even more uninteresting. So, okay, can
they be uninteresting? Well let's think
about this. And there's actually a

mathematical
proof - in inverted commas - that
says that actually there is no number
that is uninteresting, that all numbers
are interesting. It's very simple; let's
prove it by contradiction. So let's
imagine that n- we're assuming that not
all numbers are interesting, okay? So if
not all numbers are interesting then let

the number n be the least uninteresting
number.
Okay, so n is the least uninteresting
number. But now n is the least
uninteresting number so it's interesting!
Okay? So that implies that n is
interesting.
Okay, so you've immediately run into a
contradiction. Okay? So all numbers must
be interesting. Now of course this is a-
this is slightly dodgy, this proof;
this is- it's what we call self
referencing. It's a bit like statements
like 'can the Almighty create a
stone that that he can't move?' If he's
almighty he can do anything so he
should be able to create a stone that
he can't move but, you know, actually
then he can't move the stone. So there's-

(So he's not almighty?)
- So he's not
almighty. So there's something sort of
self referencing in it, so what you
really need to do is you need to define
what you mean by interesting. So you can
imagine doing that; so you say, okay,
what's a- what makes an interesting
number? Well I'll write down a list of
criteria; so maybe a prime number is
interesting. Square numbers? Pretty

interesting.
And you write down a list of
things that you think are interesting
and at some point on that list, let's say
at the number 28, say, whatever, you write
down that it's the least uninteresting
number as one of the criteria. But that's
clearly now- this is ill-defined now. So
the problem that you have here is is
that the criteria aren't well defined;
you need to draw the the conclusion
about a number before the definition is
complete, so it's it's fundamentally
flawed as a logical problem. But let's
come back to these numbers, okay?
